passages.text: China (PRC) I Comm. Equipment
2Q25 Miss: Growth at the Expense of Margin,D/G to Underperform

ZTE has rallied 52% in the past 3 months amid hopes over AI and ASIC growth, but its 2Q25 miss indicates excessive market optimism. AI growth can be seen in 200% growth in server rev, but likely at 4-5% GM. Hence,rev beat but core OP and NP missed. ZTE likely has gained server share as competitors are being US sanctioned or vulnerable to such. Telco rev (53% GM) continued to fall (-6%). Lower GM drives our forecast cut(<cons). We D/G to Uperf.

**2Q25 a big miss although rev growth beat.** ZTE's 2Q25 rev grew by 21%, due mainly to strong server rev growth, but its core OP and reported NP fell 32%/13%. Although its rev beat cons by 12%, its core OP and reported NP were 25% and 2% below cons. In 1H25, its G&C (gov and enterprise) rev grew 110% YoY, driven by ~200% growth in server rev. 90% of its server rev was classified as G&C (mainly for Internet players and other enterprises) and the rest classified as carrier (sold to telcos). Even if 55% of its server rev comes from AI servers (using both US and local chips), we estimate its GM at only 4-5%. That is why its G&C GM in 1H25 fell sharply YoY from 21.8% to 8.3%. ZTE's most important rev category, carrier, which was still 49% of total rev in 1H25, fell 6% and saw a GM decline of 1.4ppt to 52.9%. The rev decline was driven mainly by weak Chinese telco capex. We believe Chinese telco capex will continue to fall, as 5G capex has peaked but 6G is still far away (likely 2028/29), and the three telcos have been tightly controlling costs and capex as their revenue growth has slowed to 1%. Its consumer business (smartphone+home terminals) saw 8% rev growth in 1H25 but GM also dropped by 1.2ppt to 17.8%. We are cautious on the outlook of the consumer business in 2H25, driven by our bearish view on smartphone (Android in particular), and more competition in the home terminal market (modem, router and set-top boxes).

**Server growth brings rev growth but not profit growth.** We estimate ZTE's China server market share will grow from 2.1% in 2024 to 6% in 2025. ~90% of its server rev is generated from non-telcos, meaning Internet players and enterprise customers. The significant market share gain is likely driven by the fact that 1) China's largest server player has been US sanctioned, 2) the next two largest server players are also vulnerable to US sanctions, but 3) ZTE has very low sanctionable risk given it has already paid the US govt a large settlement penalty and is still being monitored by the US DoC. We estimate server assembly generates 4% to 5% GM, vs carrier at 40%+. We estimate ZTE's server market share could grow further to 10% in the next three years, but its carrier rev will continue to see negative growth in 2025/26/27. That would gradually blended GM down from ~38% in 2024 to ~25% in 2028E.

**Cut forecasts and below consensus.** Our reduced NP forecasts are 26%/31% below cons in 2026/26. We see ZTE's 22x 2025E PE against negative NP growth in the next 3 years as attractive. U/G to Underperf, though we raise PT.
Equity ResearchAugust 31,2025

Edison Lee, CFA * | Equity Analyst
Annie Ping, CFA, FRM * | Equity Associate
Nick Cheng * | Equity Analyst
Jacky He * | Equity Analyst
Matt Ma * | Equity Analyst

- Chinese telcos' capex has peaked and their 2025 capex guidance implies \(9.7\%\) YoY decline. We expect Chinese telco capex decline would decelerate, while overseas telco capex would at best grow at low single digit %. 
- Huawei's access to China's expansion in 28nm/14nm/7nm foundry capacity would allow it to regain market share and competitive edge in products such as 5G BTS and AI servers. 
- ZTE will likely benefit from China's AI server capex up cycle but those non-telco hardware generates much lower GM than telecom equipment. ZTE's margin will likely be dragged by low-margin server business, as its server business is expected to grow rapidly and has higher revenue mix.
Risk/Reward - 12 Month View

- China's telco capex falls by a CAGR of -2.3% between 2025 and 2028. 
- Int'l telco capex is flat between 2025 and 2028. 
- ZTE's blended market share in China (as a % of industry capex) rises from 15.0% in 2024 to 16.1% in 2028. 
- ZTE's G&C/Consumer business rises by 25.2%/8.4% CAGR in 2025-28. Its carrier rev contribution falls to 58% in 2024 and further falls to 35% in 2028. 
- Blended GM falls from 37.9% in 2024 to 25.3% in 2028. 
- PT of HK\$27.27 based on DCF valuation (11.3% WACC and -5% terminal growth). PT implies 8.2x 2030E EV/EBITDA, 17.7x 2030E P/E.

1. Building a best-in-class compliance management system that meets all the Regulatory requirements in different countries such as the US, EU, and China. 
2. Pursue reduced carbon emission for both itself and its telecom customers.

1. Promote the importance of compliance to all employees and provide relevant training, aiming for zero case of non-compliance. 
2. Strengthen legal research and risk management and build a top-level in-house team to handle legal and compliance issues in different countries.
1. What compliance system has ZTE built to address compliance issues in overseas countries especially the US?

- Same Chinese telco capex as in base case. 
- Lower gross margin by 0-1.0 ppt than the base case due to intensified competition. 
- Blended share in China's carrier market lower by 0-2ppt than in the base case as HW's return has a bigger impact. 
- Same int'l telco shares assumptions. 
- PT of HK\$16.80 based on DCF valuation (11.3% WACC and -6% terminal growth).

- Chinese telcos' 2025 capex guidance will likely show continued decline. 
- Chinese telcos' equipment tenders continue to show slower market share gain for ZTE. 
- Consensus earnings forecasts will need to fall for the next 3 years.
- China's AI server capex continue to increase.
2. What R&D efforts have been spent in assessing business opportunities and continuities when technologies in telecom industries are fast evolving?

ZTE is principally engaged in the design, development, production, distribution and installation of a broad range of advanced telecommunications equipment, including carriers" networks, handsets, and telecommunications software systems and services. It is the fourth- largest integrated telecom network equipment maker globally.

Price target is based on DCF valuation at \(11.3\%\) WACC, and \(- 5\%\) terminal growth (implying 18x 2030E PE). Key upside risks are 1) further market share gain in server if more Chinese server players are sanctioned by the US; 2) telcos accelerating 6G buildout resulting in rising capex; and 3) more significant div payout increase and/or a large share buyback program. Key downside risks are 1) lower- than- expected 7nm capacity expansion by Chinese foundries leading to lower Al capex, 2) failure by Chinese foundries to ramp up yield for GPU, and 3) failure by Chinese Al companies to commercialize Al applications, leading to depressed Al capex.
Article 3(1)e and Article 7 of MAR) Recommendation Published Recommendation Distributed

Buy - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of \(15\%\) or more within a 12- month period. Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period.
NR - The investment rating and price target have been temporarily suspended. Such suspensions are in compliance with applicable regulations and/or Jefferies policies.
CS - Coverage Suspended. Jefferies has suspended coverage of this company.
NC - Not covered. Jefferies does not cover this company.

Restricted - Describes issuers where, in conjunction with Jefferies engagement in certain transactions, company policy or applicable securities regulations prohibit certain types of communications, including investment recommendations.
Monitor - Describes securities whose company fundamentals and financials are being monitored, and for which no financial projections or opinions on the investment merits of the company are provided.

Jefferies methodology for assigning ratings may include the following: market capitalization, maturity, growth/value, volatility and expected total return over the next 12 months. The price targets are based on several methodologies, which may include, but are not restricted to, analyses of market risk, growth rate, revenue stream, discounted cash flow (DCF), EBITDA, EPS, cash flow (CF), free cash flow (FCF), EV/EBITDA, P/E, PE/growth, P/CF, P/FCF, premium (discount)/average group EV/EBITDA, premium (discount)/average group P/E, sum of the parts, net asset value, dividend returns, and return on equity (ROE) over the next 12 months.

Jefferies Franchise Picks include stock selections from among the best stock ideas from our equity analysts over a 12 month period. Stock selection is based on fundamental analysis and may take into account other factors such as analyst conviction, differentiated analysis, a favorable risk/reward ratio and investment themes that Jefferies analysts are recommending. Jefferies Franchise Picks will include only Buy rated stocks and the number can vary depending on analyst recommendations for inclusion. Stocks will be added as new opportunities arise and removed when the reason for inclusion changes, the stock has met its desired return, if it is no longer rated Buy and/or if it triggers a stop loss. Stocks having 120 day volatility in the bottom quartile of S&P stocks will continue to have a \(15\%\) stop loss, and the remainder will have a \(20\%\) stop. Franchise Picks are not intended to represent a recommended portfolio of stocks and is not sector based, but we may note where we believe a Pick falls within an investment style such as growth or value.
